name: Consistency
summary:
In deductive logic, a consistent theory is one that does not lead to a logical contradiction. A theory 
  
    
      
        T
      
    
    {\displaystyle T}
  
 is consistent if there is no formula 
  
    
      
        φ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \varphi }
  
 such that both 
  
    
      
        φ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \varphi }
  
 and its negation 
  
    
      
        ¬
        φ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \lnot \varphi }
